to a slave ol the institutus had been supported by the Sabinians: the Proculians held it void in either case: Servius maintained that the bequest was provisionally valid‚ whether conditional or not, but became void if the legatee was in the institutus’ power on the dies legati cedens, Gaius ii. 244. The Proculian view was based upon what is called the regula Catoniana, because it was ascribed to one ol the Catos : ‘regula Catoniana sic definit; quod, si testamenti lacti tempore decessisset testator, inutile soret, id legatum, quandocunque decesserit, non valere' Dig. 34. 7. 1. But this rule did not apply to conditional legacies, whose validity was tested at the fulfilment of the condition, Dig. 35. 1. 98, orto those which were given ex die: ‘Catoniana regula non pertinet ad ea legata, quorum dies non mortis tempore, sed post aditam cedit heredi· tatem' Dig. 34. 7. 3.
